translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Kuṭaja Flower Birth Stories
The Elder Pañcahatthi
“The Fortunate One was called Tisso,
the chief in the world, the best of men;🔽He was going along the street
with his disciples in front.🔽I had four women set up
five handfuls of lotuses;
I wanted to give an offering,
and I set out for the attainment of the wind.
The One Well-Gone, who was golden-coloured,
was going along the street;
I was touched by the Buddha’s rays,
and I worshipped the Best of Men.
For twenty-two eons from now
I worshipped with that flower;
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of worshipping the Buddha.
For thirteen eons from now

analyzed: pañca susabha sammatā  satta ratana sampannā
translated: there were five who were called Susabha;🔽They were powerful wheel-turning kings,
endowed with the seven treasures.
The four discriminations …
… the Buddha’s instruction has been accomplished.”🔽Thus the venerable Elder Pañcahatthi recited these verses.

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā pañcahatthiyo thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.🔽Pañcahatthiyattherassāpadānaṁ catutthaṁ.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā pañcahatthiyaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati 🔽pañcahatthiya therassa apadānam catuttha
translated: The Elder Pañcahatthi’s Birth Story, the fourth.
